WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 412 August 1980 HEALTH ISSUES AND POLICIES IN THE DEVELOPING COUNTRIES A Background Study for World Development Report, 1980 After two decades of neglect, health has reappeared as a significant concern among development authorities and financing institutions. This paper focuses on the principal health policy issues that are expected to confront national authorities in developing countries over the next two decades. It also examines problems in the organization and operation of basic health services, and the financing of health care. Recent studies have shown that modern medical technology has been a major factor influencing health in the developing countries. These studies also suggest that improvements in housing, sanitation, and hygiene have contributed more modestly to improvements in health in developing countries than they did in the economies now advanced. The immediate sector priority therefore is to broaden access to the most cost-effective elements of modern health care. The most promising solution to the problem of geographic access is primary health care, defined as essential health care provided in the community by relying upon-community resources. Although the idea has strong political support, strategies for its large-scale implementation have not yet been devised. This paper explores the organizational and institutional problems that must be overcome and examines mechanisms for financing primary health care.  INTRODUCTION This paper was prepared as background for the third World Develop- ment Report. It focuses on the major health policy issues that are expected to confront national authorities in developing countries over the next two decades. It is written primarily for an audience of political leaders, development technicians, and health bureaucrats. The paper does not pursue medical-technical issues but rather addresses problems in the organization and operation of basic health services, and the financing of health care. After two decades of neglect, health has reappeared as a significant concern among development authorities and financing institutions. From the mid 1950s through the early 1970s, efforts to improve human health were treated, at best, as adding consumption and, more typically, as contributing in a nega- tive way to excessive population growth and consequent economic impoverishment. This line of thought limited technical and financial assistance to the sector and discouraged critical assessment of broad policies and operational pro- grams in health. In the early 1970s a number of new discoveries and shifts of emphasis in development thinking restored interest in the health sector. The following changes were of critical importance: First, the view that better health necessaril results in acceler- ated population growth was challenged. The alternative hypothhih rates of infant mortality motivate high birth rates--received empirical sup- port and gained widespread political acceptance. A majority of countries attending the Bucharest Conference on Population in 1974 strongly endorsed the notion that economic development and health improvements are prerequi- sites for fertility decline. Second, attention focused on development of human resources as development oc he dfetwrdibUtn foef b fits from economic growth. High levels of disease among the very poor clearly lower their capacity to learn and to adapt, thus reducing the effective labor supply. Improvements in health would promote learning, reduce absenteeism, improve stamina, and increase energy output. Therefore, better health, espe- cially among adults, would contribute to improving the economic status of the poor and to expanding total output. Third, the international concern in the mid 1970s for achieving human rights and meeting basic human needs reoriented development programs to alleviate further the symptoms of poverty. High rates of illness and pre- mature death in developing countries stood out as examples of the failure of development to meet human needs. Fourth, evidence appeared indicating that a number of low income countries had succeeded in significantly reducing disease, using simple low- cost methods of health care. The fact that these methods were within the economic resources of even the poorest countries gave improving health care additional urgency, and thus confirmed the feasibility of health care for all.

The concept of primary health care has been advanced as the most promising solution to the problem of geographic access. Primary health care is defined as essential health care provided in the community by relying upon community resources. It must be technically appropriate and acceptable to beneficiaries. It includes maternal and child health care, immunization, care of iniuries and promotion of nutrition and sanitation. Although the concept has strong political support, a strategy for its large-scale imple- mentation has not yet been devised. In order to achieve the goal of access to health care, organizational and institutional problems must be overcome and suitable financing mechanisms must be developed.
 Health Conditions and Resources in 1980 For the developing countries as a group, life expectancy at birth is about 54 years. There are, however, major regional differences: life expectancy in Africa is now about 46 years; in South Asia it is about 51 years, and in Latin America, about 63 years. In contrast, life expectancy in the more developed countries is Just over 70 years. 1/ The low life expectancy in developing countries is due largely to v 4f& > very high death rates among children. In the poorest districts of very low-i income countries half of all children die during the first year of life. However, major regional differences in child mortality rates (like life expectancy) exist. In Africa, for example, the infant mortality rate is more than 120 deaths per 1,000 live births, compared with 53 in Latin America and 15 in Europe and North America. 2/ For those in developing countries who reach the age of five, life expectancy is only eight to nine years less than in developed countries. These survivors suffer frequently, however, from nonfatal diseases. Detailed data on health conditions, including morbidity, are available for only a few countries and even then are of doubtful accuracy. The few detailed studies available suggest that illness disrupts normal activities for roughly one- tenth of people's time in most developing countries. In contrast, residents of more developed countries report that illnesses interferes with normal activities about 5 percent of the time. The definition of "incapacitating illness" appears to differ with wealthier people being more willing to halt work or to escape usual responsibilities. Many nonfatal illnesses are inter- mittent with recurrent acute episodes; these illnesses disrupt economic activity, often at critical times, such as the planting and harvesting seasons in the case of malaria. Chronic and debilitating diseases impair mental con- centration, learning ability and economic productivity. Degenerative chronic diseases such as heart disease, stroke, diabetes, and cancer, are less preva- lent in developing than in developed countries, primarily because a small proportion of the total population has survived to late adulthood. These diseases are becoming serious problems in the developing countries, however, especially among affluent, middle-aged, urbanized persons. Accidental injuries are also emerging as a major cause of death and disability in many countries. Intercountry Variations in Health Health conditions vary more among the less developed countries than between more and less developed ones. Life expectancy varies from about 40 years (Mali, Angola, and Upper Volta) to about 70 years (Sri Lanka, Singapore, and Argentina). Life expectancy generally rises with per capita incomes, thus lending credence 1/ World Bank, World Development Report, 1980, Washington, D.C., 1980. 2/ United Nations, Demographic Estimates and Projections.

But the high levels of health in a few very poor areas (Sri Lanka and the Indian state of Kerala, for example) and the low life expectancy in a smaller number of relatively wealthy areas (Brazil and Nigeria) demonstrate that the relation- ship is neither simple nor inescapable. Moreover, the pattern of disease and the scale of morbidity both vary widely across geographic areas. The differences reflect not only variations in income levels, environmental sanitation, access to health care, levels of education, etc., but also such uncontrollable factors as climate. Life expectancy ranges from 39 years to 54 years (lower than the average for India). It is estimated that at least a million African children die each year without reaching the age of five. In much of Africa, half of all deaths occur among children under five.  - 12 - National Health Care Expenditures Although expenditures for health care in developing countries are modest, they are much greater than is generally acknowledged. In Africa, governments report spending from $1 to $55 per capita a year; in Latin America and the Caribbean, governments report outlays of up to $68. However, the figures fail to account for many health-related expenditures. Officially reported health expenditures are obtained by the World Health Organization from national health ministries. The definition of health and the completeness of reports varies widely. For purposes of reporting, the health sector is generally defined to include delivery of medical care to individuals, mass immunization, and control of vector-borne diseases. Activ- ities such as monitoring outbreaks of disease and monitoring of air quality, food processing, water supply, and waste disposal are sometimes included if these functions are under the direct control of the national ministry of health. Activities in health and hygiene education, environmental sanitation, family planning, food fortification, solid waste disposal, rodent control, etc., that are typically overseen by other ministries but are nonetheless undertaken primarily to promote health, are rarely included. Operating and capital budgets are also poorly distinguished. Many ministries of health do not separate budgets for operating units into recur- rent and development expenditures. In addition, frequently development activ- ities--training, construction, well drilling, etc.--are undertaken by other agencies and the capital costs are not accounted for at all by the ministry of health. The value of the services of these capital goods is frequently omitted from reports of health expenditures, thus understating the current efforts in health. A number of countries--India, Brazil, and Nigeria, for example- delegate responsibility for health care to local governments or states. In addition, most Latin American and a growing number of Asian countries have established social security programs or health insurance schemes that finance health care. The completeness of reports of spending on health by agencies other than national ministries of health varies widely from country to country, further undermining the validity and comparability of the published data. Thus, intercountry comparisons are hazardous. Conversion of Health Expenditures into US Dollars: Expenditures in local currency are usually converted into US dollars, using official exchange rates. In order to provide a somewhat more realistic picture of health bud- gets, they are also presented here in terms of purchasing power parity with US dollars. This further adjustment seeks to recognize major differences among countries in the cost of labor. 29/ Ideally the labor component of 29/ The present calculations are based upon the method devised by Isenman. Private Sector Expenditures for Health: Amounts spent by individ- uals and private voluntary organizations are not documented except in a handful of countries. Private sector expenditures include fees required by public facilities, illegal payments to obtain drugs or preferential treatment

In many developing countries, payments to pharmacists and to traditional health workers repre- sent a prominent part of total health expenditures. In addition to direct payments for goods and services, substantial expenditures are made for transportation to health facilities and for food and lodging while at the facility. Often a second person must accompany the person seeking care, thereby doubling these indirect costs. A study of Makerere University Hos- pital in Uganda revealed that the costs of travel exceeded half the direct cost of care, even though this is a sophisticated referral hospital. 30/ In rural areas, where distances are greater and the level of care (and hence direct operating costs) more modest, travel costs probably represent a larger share of the total costs of health care. Several attempts have been made to estimate private expenditures for health care in developing countries. These studies have been based on both household expenditures surveys and studies of the receipts of providers; a few investigations have sought to reconcile these two sources of data in order to obtain more precise values. The major difficulty in estimating pri- vate expenditures has been the reluctance of individuals to report spending for traditional and indigenous forms of health care, and for illegal payments to government officials for drugs or preferential treatment. Expenditures by private voluntary organizations are also difficult to measure. Those operated from developed countries often obtain supplies and staff either free or at concessionary prices. Thus, the documented receipts and expenditures of missions and philantrophic groups tend to under- state the value of their efforts. However, the inputs supplied to such organizations often are not well adapted to local needs and thus should not be valued at full market price. Private voluntary organizations are espe- cially important in Africa and South Asia. Table 11 presents a detailed accounting of health expenditures for three countries. It reveals that reported public spending for health may represent as little as a third of total spending, exclusive of the cost of travel and maintenance necessary to obtain care. This information suggests that the quantity of resources being committed to health is much greater than is generally acknowledged, implying that the financial constraints to pro- viding basic health services are much less severe than is commonly asserted. Reallocation of private resources, however, is not likely to be easy unless considerable attention is paid to the acceptability to clients of new forms of health care. The significant and growing capacities of medical technology to control spe- cific disease should be made widely accessible.  - 31 - Operational Issues in Improving Access to Health Care Although the technology of simplified medical care has been exten- sively tested, the development of institutional arrangements and mechanisms to control the quality of services and use of resources is in its infancy. 1/ The proponents of primary health care have not devised means for coordinat- ing the activities of ministries and bureaucracies controlling nutrition, education, water supply, sanitation, and occupational safety, nor have they succeeded in convincing those outside the health field that the activities of these other sectors ought to be evaluated largely (or even solely) in terms of their contributions to health. Integration A central tenet of primary health care is that improvements in health are produced by such causal factors as nutrition, education, sanita- tion, water, occupational safety, personal health care, control of disease vectors, and mass immunization. Moreover, the contributions made to health by, for example, nutrition education, improvements in the environment, and socioeconomic development are asserted to depend upon interventions that are simultaneously undertaken; interventions are alleged to have synergistic effects. This assertion, if correct, implies that health programming ought to be conducted in an integrated manner. Health certainly is affected by a wide range of factors. Thus synergistic activities undertaken concurrently by several ministries might yield greater benefits to health. However, it does not follow that inte- gration of field activities is necessary. Those inputs that are separable from one another in determining health may be distinguished from those that yield significantly greater benefits when jointly employed. In the first instance, vector-borne parasitic diseases such as malaria and schistosomia- sis can be controlled by destroying the habitat of the vector, applying pesticides, or administering drugs to victims or potential victims. Clearly, the choice of method to be employed should reflect systematic analysis of the costs, benefits, and risks attached to each approach or to combinations of approaches, but one approach can be substituted for the other. In the second instance, it is argued that interventions produce additional benefits if undertaken jointly. For example, bacterial and viral infections increase nutritional requirements and in some instances impair absorption of nutrients. Moreover, the severity of infectious disease and the efficiency of body defenses against an invading parasite are influenced by nutritional status. Thus joint efforts to improve nutrition and to prevent and/or treat infectious diseases yield significantly greater benefits than these interventions introduced individually. 1/ Kenneth Newell, Health by the People, Geneva: World Health Organization, 1975.

It is possible to generate community participation. Assessment of the clinical and interpersonal skill of these trainees suggests that community health workers are as well prepared to respond to common health care needs as are professional health workers. Though the technical feasibility of low-cost, community-based health care is well established, there have not been successful large-scale programs for rural or low-income urban populations. Those schemes that have succeeded have often been small in scale and closely supervised by their developers. The problems that must be anticipated in large-scale programs result primarily from breakdowns in management and logistics. This may be due to inadequate financing, transport failures, or lack of personnel and inventory management. Problems may also result from lack of continuing education and inadequately executed administrative and technical supervi- sion. Supporting activities such as logistics of supplies, appropriate management, and the quality of supervision are critically important. The discrepancy between the promises and achievements of low-cost rural health care result primarily from inadequate management, and this is a consequence of underdeveloped administrative machinery and lack of organization among client populations.

Ministries of health generally do not have the network of stores, vehicles, or mainten- ance facilities needed to serve scattered communities. Many health bureau- cracies have not yet developed procurement procedures and inventory manage- ment systems to ensure the continuous availability of drugs and supplies. 3/ India is an example. The community health worker is supposed to be supported by the community, with only logistic links to the health care system.
 - 41 - Cooperatives and commercial distributors of drugs and supplies, such as the village pharmacies of some West African countries, may be enlisted to exploit the administrative capacities of non-governmental institutions. But promotion of these responsibilities will generally require considerable initial effort by government officials. Quality Assurance. Deprofessionalization of health care escalates the importance of supervising technical performance and monitoring utilization of health care. Health workers who have not been extensively conditioned into the role and sensitized to peer pressures are particularly likely to perform inadequately. Traditional beliefs about disease and health care, which are typical of rural areas, further complicate the task of health workers. Mobilization of Financial Resources. Although the new health care technolo- gies have much lower unit costs than conventional approaches, the total budgetary commitment to health must, nonetheless, be substantially increased. Existing health care programs, no matter how inappropriate, rarely can be discontinued, so additional resources must be found. This requires that the health bureaucracy prepare convincing budget presentations stressing low-cost technologies and improved access to care -- subjects about which the existing bureaucracies frequently know little, and to which they may have only modest commitment. Moreover, the political authorities to whom the presentations are addressed often have conservative views about health care. A number of observers have urged that local self-help be used to finance rural primary health care. However, this requires that government health authorities develop the necessary local organizations. Furthermore, local financing raises problems of accountability for substantial sums of money by large numbers of dispersed organizations over which governments rarely have effective control. Local self-help also works systematically against the poorest communities. Building Community Organizations. Because rural health services must necessarily be provided through highly dispersed facilities and by auxiliary staff, continuous supervision is both essential and difficult. Organized (formal or informal) consumer groups, so-called "informed publics", can provide oversight, especially of timely performance of duties and accounta- bility for resources. To be effective, local interest groups must be sufficiently organized and articulate to influence government officials. This requires building an informed public and effective leadership -- an entirely new task for most health bureaucracies. In addition, strengthening local organiza- tions often requires delegation of responsibilities and provision of funds to carry out prescribed tasks; yet government agencies are frequently prohibited by law or regulations from offering such assistance. Where local organizations have been installed by ministries of health, long-term viabil- ity has emerged as a problem. Frequently, these entities have collapsed because the community has seen them to be ineffective.
 - 42 - The Village Family Planning Program in Indonesia illustrates the development of a local constituency for health activities.4/ The Village Family Planning Program began in late 1974, as a small pilot project in West Java to test the feasibility of using local communities as contraceptive resupply points. The project proved the feasibility of village resupply, and from fifty such depots in late 1974, the program expanded rapidly in three years to include 20,000 village depots and 60,000 family planning groups. Contraceptives are sent from the clinic to the village depot. The depot is either in a villager's home or a village administrative office, and is run by a village volunteer who is usually a satisfied client of the family planning program, or a member of the village administration staff. A family planning fieldworker plays an important role in linking the clinic with the village, and in making supplies available to ensure that contra- ceptives are on hand for eligible couples. Each family planning group is led by a woman who is responsible for ensuring that her members are resupplied with pills and condoms. She also acts as a reference point for women with questions or complaints, and may refer women to the clinic. The family planning fieldworkers, who are temporary government employees, have been effective in providing limited and specific services. The consistency and regularity of contact with village groups and committees have been the most important factors in developing and maintaining a well- organized, motivated community organization. As the program has become established, interest in other health-related services has increased, for example, in nutrition and emergency health care. The most significant outcome of this program is that it has tended to make family planning a village-oriented, rather than a clinic- oriented, activity, thus transferring some of the responsibility for managing and implementing services from the government to the community. Although there are a number of ways to build a local constituency, perhaps the most important approach is to ensure that new health programs are responsive to locally perceived needs. Health programs may be classi- fied into popular and unpopular programs. Although water supply, maternal and child care, and curative services are commonly perceived to be valuable, sanitation, health education, and preventive programs are not particularly popular and are rarely considered important by the beneficiaries. Thus, these latter activities are unsuitable for strengthening local response. Priority should be placed on strengthening those community organizations which support local initiatives. For example, governments may offer grants-in-aid to groups that organize efforts to construct facili- ties or mobilize local labor. To be effective, these grants must be matched with enthusiasm from an organized interest group. It is important to develop capacity within such groups both for identifying local priori- ties, and for expressing their importance to political authorities and the 4/ Indonesia: Health Sector Overview, World Bank, 1978, unpublished.
 - 43 - formal bureaucracy. Another option is to encourage existing community organizations with effective and articulate leadership to assume oversight responsibility for local health activities. Community organizations are not likely to develop rapidly or to be entirely effective. But without local institutions or an informed public capable of demanding a minimum level of performance from the rural health care system, there is little hope for its long-term success. Strengthening Institutional Capacity Low-cost rural health activities require a complex and sophisticated administrative superstructure, and new procedures for delivery of supplies, personnel management, utilization and quality control, institution-building, marketing, and monitoring. They require an administration-intensive approach different from present admiinistrative patterns. Strengthening the Formal Bureaucracy Efforts to increase the capacity of the formal bureaucracy can be introduced at several stages in the development of a program. At the design stage, the management capacity of the ministry of health should be assessed. Particular attention should be paid to the past performance of its rural health unit, especially in very remote areas of the country. Insights into the capacities of the unit can often be obtained from an analysis of training programs, personnel management, and budgeting. These three activities most clearly reveal the priorities of the unit and its ability to initiate and operate new programs. Such an analysis also provides a sense for the level of bureaucratic development, the weaknesses in staffing, the extent to which standard procedures have been established, and the ability of the unit to effect changes. From this assessment, one can identify needs for training staff, strengthening communications between center and periphery, formalizing procedures, and improving communications with field staff. During tAie implementation phase, the ministry must mobilize new resources, issue tenders and evaluate bids, award contracts, supervise construction activities, devise curricula, recruit personnel, initiate training, and establish operating and personnel policies. Commonly, a special project management unit (PHU) is established to expedite these activities. It is allowed to recruit staff outside civil service regula- tions and often is granted exceptional authority to make contracts. The PMU, however, frequently attracts the best administrative talent from the ministry of health, thereby impoverishing the ministry. Later attempts to reintegrate the staff of a PHU into the formal bureaucracy are often unsuccessful. Thus, the PTMU concept should be used sparingly and only for programs of limited duration. If, instead, a new program is implemented through the regular line departments in the health institutions, considerable opportunity emerges for introducing new techniques or strengthening existing standard operating procedures. This is particularly important for health bureaucracies, since they are often not familiar with procedures used in other institutions in dealing, for example, with construction, logistics, procurement, and personnel management.
 - 44 - During the operational phase, machinery should be created to monitor continuously not only field operations but also the performance of management. The usefulness of activity reports, clinical records, and supervision activities should be carefully scrutinized. These functions absorb considerable staff time, and are likely to engender cynicism toward the management system if they do not contribute directly to the performance of clinical activities. Although these concepts are commonly applied in business enter- prises,5/ they are not often used by public managers, whose decisions are constrained in peculiar ways by civil service rules and other considera- tions. Nonetheless, within these constraints, possibilities of introducing problem-oriented management are available. For example, it is possible to shift the focus of supervision of local health workers from administrative control to training and facilitating. More radical changes necessary to introduce problem-oriented management or to increase organizational flexibility and learning capacity would require major administrative reforms. However, these reforms are often not feasible or even advisable, since they have a destabilizing effect. But there are options for marginal changes, particularly in the areas of supervision and logistics. Exploiting these might lead, as the case of Indonesia shows, to increased community response. Project Concepts Projects should conserve administrative capacity. Wholesale intro- duction of innovations not only overwhelms the implementation capabilities of the ministry of health but also frequently exceeds the ability of villag- ers to accommodate change. Thus, a strategy for change should be devised that gradually develops operating capacities. Relatively simple activities, sometimes only of modest public health importance, should be introduced first, with gradual expansion of the range of services. In addition, flexibility is needed during project implementation. The weakness of plan- ning tools, uncertainty about problems, social structure, unpredictability of administrative capacity, and political change will often require devia- tions from a prescribed plan. Thus, the plan should provide for these contingencies. The complexity of a project has major implications for administra- tive capacity. In general, projects should be as simple as possible. How- ever, it appears that each individual project should represent a balanced portfolio of technical risk, financial commitments, and political conse- quences. In the health sector, the controversy over the desirability of integration has focused on the issue of whether to develop vertical (single-disease) programs or horizontal programs dealing simultaneously 5/ David Korten, Population and Social Development Management, Caracas, Venezuela: IESA, 1979.
 - 45 - with a number of health problems.6/ Although relatively simple single- disease intervention programs have proved to be effective, at the field level they have also demonstrated the problems of centralized line opera- tions in terms of rigidity, and the excessive costs of coordination attached to them. On the other hand, highly integrated approaches have led to the complex coordination problems outlined earlier. 6/ Background papers: Health and Population in Developing Countries, Bellagio, 1979; in particular, Stephen Joseph and Sharon Stanton Russell, "Is Primary Health Care the Wave of the Future"; and J. Walsh and K. Warren, "Selective Primary Health Care".
 - 46 - Financing Health Care As noted earlier, substantial amounts are being spent by govern- ments, voluntary organizations, and individuals to promote health. Our analyses suggest that, in most countries, a basic program of health care could be provided to everyone with no additional expenditure. There are serious obstacles, however, to such a reallocation of funds. Even so, the growth in aggregate incomes in the developing countries and the high-income elasticity of demand for health may be expected to yield very significant additions to expenditures for health care. Much of this spending could be allocated to achieve broad access to care with little sacrifice of the interests of those segments of the population that are now better served. Financial Requirements The experiences of the World Bank suggest that development cost of providing basic health care to those not now served is US$10-12 billion. This investment would provide prenatal care, trained midwifery, childhood immunization, treatment of injuries, control of endemic disease (e.g., vector control, suppressive drug treatment, radical curative treatment, and/or immunization), and health education. Population growth between 1980 and the year 2000 will add 1.4 to 1.6 billion people to the ranks of the underserved, and will thus require an additional investment of approximately US$10 billion (in 1980 dollars), beginning with annual outlays of US$400 million in the early 1980s and increasing to about US$1 billion a year by 2000. In addition, annual operating costs must increase by about US$6 billion a year in the early 1980s, rising to perhaps US$18 billion a year over 1980 levels by the year 2000. The development budget for health (including health manpower training) is now on the order of US$2 billion a year for the developing countries, excluding China. Their operating budgets for health are about US$17.5 billion a year in total.l/ Total spending -- for development and operation of public systems and for direct and indirect private expenditures -- is about US$70 billion a year. Over the next two decades, total expenditures for health care in developing countries may be expected to more than quadruple. Thus, one may realistically expect that an additional US$200 billion will be spent annually for health care in the now-developing countries at the end of the century. Hence, even assuming that the sector will not reallocate resources away from existing programs, there are substantial opportunities to modify health programs. Present Methods of Health Care Finance Two approaches to financing health care are employed by developing countries. In the overwhelming majority of developing countries, govern- ments produce and distribute modern, western-type health care. Those 1/ WHO, World Health Statistics - Resources, 1978
 - 47 - countries that attained political independence during the 1960s have been almost unanimous in adopting policies of public provision of care as a human right. A second group of countries -- especially the middle-income nations of Latin America and Asia -- have until recently operated only modest publicly financed health care programs; most services are produced by physician-entrepreneurs. These countries are now creating social insur- ance programs in order to reduce economic barriers to health care, as well as to provide disability and retirement benefits. In Latin America, coverage under social insurance programs has increased substantially over the past decade. Such expansion has been motivated by mounting awareness of the political need to build constituencies among the poor, and by adop- tion of European notions of a welfare state. The social insurance approach to health care finance has been most attractive to countries with well- established, private health sectors. The goal of social insurance is not so much to develop the health sector as to improve access to existing services reflecting the political significance of established health care institutions. Social insurance programs often have been devised for limited clienteles such as industrial workers, migrant farm workers, and civil service employees. Programs also have been created to promote nutri- tion, personal health services, disability benefits, etc., so that over- lapping and conflicting programs have emerged in many countries. Despite the growth of public financing, a substantial private sector coexists with publicly financed programs in all countries. This reflects the fact that access to government-sponsored or government- financed health care facilities remains unsatisfactory, even in countries with strong political commitment to public provision of health care. Espe- cially in rural areas, traditional indigenous practitioners provide a large proportion of care. In some countries -- especially in Africa and South Asia -- private voluntary organizations are prominent sources of care. Psychosocial disorders often are presented to indigenous health workers whose superior effectiveness has been demonstrated, even where western services are readily available. Alternative Devices for Financing Health Care The manner in which health care is financed determines both how much it will cost and who has access to services. Moreover, some financing mechanisms provide more reliable revenues, thereby facilitating long-run planning and assuring continuity of programs. The use of prices and markets to allocate health care is gener- ally not desirable. First, incomes are not distributed in the same ways as the need for health care. Women and children, who frequently have little control over family budgets, are usually most in need of care. However, their lack of economic power limits their ability to purchase basic services. Furthermore, the very poor, because of their lack of adequate shelter, nutrition and sanitation, often need health care most. Second, even where income distribution is not a problem, most consumers are not
 - 48 - well qualified to select health services. Thus, prices are not a reasonable basoaine. The inability of consumers to make sound choices reflects the compleanrLrhejr lnr-k f experiec in sele evaluating such services. Third, much health care is chosen by adults for chiren opsonstoo ill to make their own determinations of need. Thus, market-type choices are suspect unless the interests of the beneficiary and decision-maker are harmonious. Fourth, health care activities often benefit entire cmmimun,ti;R irather than only the individual who seeks care. Most obviously, control of highly communicable diseases reduces the threat to others of infection; the eradication of smallpox is the most dramatic example of the external benefits of disease control activities. However, health care activities also confer benefits on the community by simply being available to deal with an accident or outbreak of disease. This general community benefit is not adequately measured by purchases of services or the amount paid by clients of the health care system. Fifth, the health crises that stimulate use of health services are random and often cata- strophic. Thus, in lvi uause olds generally are unable to budget adequately for health care and some form of insurance or risk-sharing is needed. Two broad approaches to the problems of risk-sharing and financing are available. In countries with developed private health care systems, insurance schemes have emerged that pool the financial risks of illness. These sc emes purchase services from private providers of care, usually on a fee-for-service basis. The health insurance scheme may be organized by a national or local government or may be developed by private associations or employers, labor unions, or insurance companies. In a number of countries, broad social insurance programs covering long-term disability, retirement, and unemployment have been introduced. This indirect approach to financing health care -- relying on private providers of care and financed by public or semi-public mechanisms -- is in large part a reflection of an existing large private system of health care. The purpose of health insurance is to reduce economic barriers to care by spreading costs among the members of the insurance group. The most primitive insurance scheme is the sickness club popul stern Europe at the turn of the century. The sickness club is organized locally, often around an existing organization such as a religious community or farmers' union. It collects annual dues, and supplements, if funds are inadequate, from all members. Members are then entitled to assistance in paying for medical care. A more complex version of the sickness club is often found in industry, where the labor union or employer provides coverage for all the workers in a factory, firm, or industry. Insurance contributions are collected periodically, on ar actuarial basis to ensure adequate reserves. Management of such a plan is often assumed by a private insurance firm. These schemes often are compulsory for all eligible persons. Voluntary insurance programs preclude significant risk-sharing. Since persons who are in higher risk of serious disease benefit more than others, there is a systematic, destabilizing effect in voluntary enrollment. Those who are at relatively low risi Haveincentives to withdraw from--the scheme and/or to
 - 49 - form another group. For example, early attempts by Korea to establish private health insurance schemes were frustrated by the withdrawal of low- risk persons and selective enrollment by persons in poor health. The alternative to voluntary health insurance is the compulsory -- usually public -- social insurance scheme. Under compulsory insurance, the problem of selective mlmetisTe Finated, and costs are shared by all participants, regardless of their initial health status and their likelihood of collecting benefits. Thus, the financial viability of the scheme is assured, and premiums are set at levels that make it possible for those who suffer high risks of illness to participate. Clearly, those who achieve low risks through good hygiene, life style, preventive care, or good nutrition share in the cost of the prodigal habits of their fellow group members. The coverage of compulsory social insurance schemes is tradi- tionally limited to those who are employed in the formal wage sector, often in firms with a significant number of employees, in order to simplify administration of premiums and benefits. Thus, those who are poorest or least adequately served are most likely to be excluded-from coverage. The major virtue of a social insurance scheme is that it provides a regular and assured source of funding for health activities, which in turn encourages private suppliers to develop capacity to produce services. In middle-i-ncome developing countries, enrollment under social insurance has expanded rapidly. In Brazil, taxes have been imposed on agricultural commodities in order to pay the social insurance premiums of farm workers, whose contributions to the social insurance funds would otherwise be difficult to administer. The second approach to financing health care has been direct provision of services by public health facilities. This has been the case most requent y in eveloping countries where an extensive health care industry did not initially exist, and thus the immediate task was to expand the production of services. Such an approach permits extensive government control over the range and quality of care offered, and, perhaps more impor- tant, allows public officials to direct resources to specific geographic areas or population groups. It also places health workers on a government salary, thereby eliminating the widespread problem of uncontrolled costs that often accompanies private care on a fee-for-service basis. However, the efficiency and effectiveness of the public health care svstem depend critically on~ t-he qu t of public administration. With public provision of care, governments construct facilities, train staff, purchase supplies, and compensate health workers directly. This arrangement gives public officials control over the operations of the health care system and removes the need to compensate providers for their services. But it also eliminates the discipline inherent in production of services for private gain. Consequently, financial disciplne ov drugs, supplies, and sta f time is also lost. At the same time, private financial incentives to compromise the quality of care are also reduced.
 - 50 - Where governments have elected to produce, rather than only to finance health care, a wide range of methods to generate funds have been used. Most publicly produced health care is financed from general govern- ment revnual. In economically advanced countries, government revenues are obtained primarily from taxes on personal and business income and on sales of goods. The structure of taxation has often been carefully maintained to encourage socially desirable activities (job creation, home ownership, etc.), achieve fairly stable incomes, and improve the equity of income distribution. Governments have also imposed a number of specific taxes earmarked for social services. Levies on manufactured goods purchased by the relatively ' )affluent, such as al , are often employed, since they tend to redistribute income away from the rich and are relatively easy to apply. Similar taxes are also imposed on luxury services, such as hotel accommodations, restaurant meals, and admission to sports events and movies. When a portion of these taxes is earmarked for health care, the insecurities that accompany periodic budget decisions by politi- cal authorities are reduced to some extent, thereby permitting longer-term planning and encouraging career commitments to the health sector. Because many disease control programs depend critically on continuity in their application, such assurance of sustained financial support is important. , Direct charges for services (user charges) are imposed by many government-owned health schemes. These charges are typically only nominal, and are intended to encourage more rational use of health resources rather than to produce- signiicant revenues. The most common charge 1S a small - registration fee required of persons when they first come in with an ill- ness. This charge is expected to discourage presentation of frivolous complaints. Those who require additional care are generally not charged for subsequent visits. Direct charges for drugs provide another source of revenue. Because patients in many countries demand drug treatment, it is important both to discourage over-prescription and to generate revenues to cover the cost of dru. In a few countries (notably in West Africa), cooperative local pharmacies have been established to purchase and distribute drugs. This removes responsibility for drug logistics and control of inventories from the ministry of health.. Such a system has generally improved supplies and reduced problems of misappropriation. Where drugs ari dist-ribltd frne of charge by governments, control over diversion to private markets has proved very difficult. In a few instances, local health workers have developed extra-legal drug funds by demanding a small fee from all patients. These sums have then been used to purchase drugs from private sources in order to supplement the inadequate supplies provided by government. NatinnPl-lotteries are employed by a handful of countries to raise money to support health care activities and other social services. The net proceeds of the lottery are usually earmarked for specific programs.
 - 51 - Community Participation Publicly operated health care programs in developing countries now frequently require local participation in their financing. The most common requirement is that the community organize itself to construct a small clinic and/or a house for health workers. The community is expected to contribute labor and local materials such as sand, gravel, and timber. Government provides architectural drawings, construction supervision, and materials not available locally. A few countries have developed standard construction kits that include cement, steel reinforcing rods, doors, windows, roofing material, and hardware. Local participation in construc- tion both promotes the community's interest in the program and reduces the initial capital cost to government. Some programs require communities to provide labor from local resources to operate the health facility, either in part or in whole. The schemes have often been frustrated by problems of recruitment of local health workers, equitable worker compensation by villagers, and/or failure to sustain local participation. For example, in Papua New Guinea, communities recently refused to construct staff housing for health workers. External Assistance Many governments rely heavily on external assistance. Voluntary organizations (mostly missions) provide large sums to the poorest develop- ing countries. These funds are typically spent under the joint administra- tion of the ministry of health and the voluntary organizations. Often a mission hospital or dispensary is designated to be the government-sponsored health facility for an area, and is given subventions by the ministry of health in return for providing care within the guidelines of official government health policies. A number of bilateral assistance agencies also provide grants to low-income developing countries to train staff, construct facilities, and/or strengthen programs of health care. Historically, these funds have been provided for time-limited programs rather than for support of operating budgets. In 1979, an estimated US$880 million was provided by external grants and loans. In addition, domestic and international borrowing are occasionally used to finance capital expenditures. Most governments have been reluctant to borrow to improve health programs, preferring instead to use hard sources of finance for directly productive investments. The resurgence of interest in health and social development appears to be altering this order of priorities. Selecting a Financing Mechanism The means chosen to finance health care influence the efficiency with which care is produced and consumed, and the equity with which it is made available. A central political issue in health care finance is how to remove unreasonable economic barriers. As noted above, the distribution of health services is poorly regulated by prices and incomes. A financing mechanism should at minimum not introduce further inefficiencies, and if
 - 52 - possible ought to encourage better use of resources. Moreover, because the cost of disease -- health care, custodial care and income loss -- may be large relative to incomes, some method of financing health care at the individual level is necessary. Private lenders often are not available, and where available are prohibitively expensive; thus, a collective method for financing health care is needed. Private production of health services with reimbursement for charge though insurnce has t e of ensurin concern amon ro s fo ~ntiernal economic efficiency of programs, because the provider receives the difference hetween revenues rom insurance and his cost of rendering care. However, he is also rewarded f_or lowering the quality of care and for promoting the use of highly remunerated services. In Europe and North America, reimbursement of private providers for services has resulted in skyrocketing costs. The consumer is relieved of concern for the cost of care, and, at the same time, providers are assured of payment of their fees and charges. Countries that have national health insurance programs have attempted to impose regulations to control costs of care by setting up official fee schedules. Providers, however, have evaded these controls by modifying the classifications under which they bill the insurance program, charging for several rather than a single procedure. Follow-up treatment has also been recommended by providers to increase revenues. Two approaches have been developed to attack this problem. First, attempts have been made to reimburse providers for the complete management of a specific condition. For example, prenatal care, delivery, post-partum care, and treatment of complications of childbirth may be reimbursed at a set fee. This approach reduces the opportunities for over-billing for services, and shifts responsibility for management of the problem to the most qualified decision-maker -- the provider of health care. The second approach is to compensate the provider for providing the patient with comprehensive care for a period of time. Under this approach, the provider receives a fixed sum -- perhaps determined by the age, sex, and other objective attributes of the patient -- and in return must provide all health care required by the person. This so-called "health maintenance" approach shifts still greater responsibility onto the provider to select services that will achieve health objectives at minimum cost. A further option for improving the efficiency of insurance schemes is to shift part of the financial burden of care to the consumer. This burden should be reasonable and generally affordable, but should be large enough to discourage excessive use of health care and to increase concern for the efficiency with which care is rendered. The patient's contribution to the cost of care may be either a fixed charge for care of a particular illness or a percentage of charges, perhaps up to a specified maximum. The purpose of the fixed initial charge is to discourage overuse of health care. This charge is usually described as the "deductible" (e.g., the amount deducted from a bill before reimbursement by the insurer) in affluent countries, and is set at about half a day's pay for a skilled worker. In developing countries, this charge is described as the "registration" fee and
 - 53 - is a much smaller percentage of incomes. Additional services are not billed to the consumers. In some areas of the world, notably West Africa, payments appear to increase the beneficiaries' esteem for a service. 7 y Direct operation of health facilities by government eliminates the perverse economic incentives of private production of health care but, at the same time, introduces new problems. In all countries, access to health care is, to some extent, inequitable, but in low-income countries, the scarcity of resources and the absence of modern amenities in rural areas produces very sharp differences in access between urban and rural areas. A more serious defect of publicly provided health programs is that they do not possess any internal, automatic mechanisms for financial, economic, and technical control. With private provision of care, the profit motive ensures some concern for costs and, with a properly designed insurance scheme, costs are articulated to consumers, thus producing some measure of accountability for these costs, and for the level, range and quality of services. Health care workers who are salaried government employees do not have the same incentives to achieve efficiency. However, where local interest groups are well-organized and politically significant, accountability may approach the levels of private systems. More frequently, local accountability is weak, with consequent inefficiency. The manner in which resources (especially drugs) are allocated to communities is especially important. Where local health workers are allowed to draw against central stores, there is a tendency to overuse drugs, recognizing that, if one doesn't overprescribe, others will, so that, regardless, supplies will be depleted prematurely. In many instances, health workers have supplemented their meager incomes by requisitioning drugs that they sell to patients, to retailers, or in some instances export to neighboring countries. Because of the very rudimentary inventory controls and lack of local accountability, these practices are difficult to document.

doc.repnme: Health problems and policies in the developing countries
doc.abstracts: After two decades of neglect, health has reappeared as a significant concern among development authorities and financing institutions. Recent studies have shown that modern medical technology has been a major factor influencing health in the developing countries. These studies also suggest that improvements in housing, sanitation, and hygiene have contributed more modestly to improvements in health in developing countries than they did in the economies now advanced. The immediate sector priority therefore is to broaden access to the most cost-effective elements of modern health care. The most promising solution to the problem of geographic access is primary health care, defined as essential health care provided in the community by relying upon community resources. Although the idea has strong political support, strategies for its large-scale implementation have not yet been devised. This paper explores the organizational and institutional problems that must be overcome and examines mechanisms for financing primary health care.
